titleStmt.title: Directed Alternative Splicing in Nijmegen Breakage Syndrome: Proof of Principle Concerning Its Therapeutical Application

analytic.title: Directed Alternative Splicing in Nijmegen Breakage Syndrome: Proof of Principle Concerning Its Therapeutical Application

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: Over 90% of patients with Nijmegen breakage syndrome (NBS), a hereditary cancer disorder, are homoallelic for a 5 bp deletion in the NBN gene involved in the cellular response to DNA damage.
This hypomorphic mutation leads to a carboxy-terminal protein fragment, p70-nibrin, with some residual function.
Average age at malignancy, typically lymphoma, is 9.7 years.
NBS patients are hypersensitive to chemotherapeutic and radiotherapeutic treatments, thus prevention of cancer development is of particular importance.
Expression of an internally deleted NBN protein, p80-nibrin, has been previously shown to be associated with a milder cellular phenotype and absence of cancer in a 62-year-old NBS patient.
Here we show that cells from this patient, unlike other NBS patients, have DNA replication and origin firing rates comparable to control cells.
We used here antisense oligonucleotides to enforce alternative splicing in NBS patient cells and efficiently generate the same internally deleted p80-nibrin protein.
Injecting the same antisense sequences as morpholino oligomers (VivoMorpholinos) into the tail vein of a humanized NBS murine mouse model also led to efficient alternative splicing in vivo.
Thus, proof of principle for the use of antisense oligonucleotides as a potential cancer prophylaxis has been demonstrated.

Patients with the rare autosomal recessive Nijmegen breakage syndrome (NBS; MIM 251260) are characterized by microcephaly and growth retardation, life threatening, however, is an immunodeficiency and, particularly, a greatly increased cancer risk.
Malignancy develops before the age of 20 in over 40% of patients. 1
World wide prevalence is estimated at 1:100,000 live births, however, NBS is particularly common in Eastern Europe with carrier frequencies as high as 1:155 in some populations.
No specific treatment is available for NBS patients beyond γ-globulin replacement therapy.
Indeed, treatment of malignancy in NBS is particularly difficult since the underlying gene, NBN (nibrin), is involved in the cellular response to DNA damage. 2,3

The consequent hypersensitivity of NBS patients severely limits therapeutic options and standard chemotherapeutics such as cyclophosphamide must be used at lower doses and radiotherapy completely avoided. 4

Tackling the cause of increased malignancy is thus an important objective for clinical management of NBS and other hereditary cancer syndromes, such as Ataxia telangiectasia and Fanconi anemia, with similar defects in DNA damage recognition and repair.
The vast majority of NBS patients are homozygous for a founder mutation, a five base pair deletion in exon 6 of the NBN gene (c.657_661del5,

This is in fact a hypomorphic mutation which leads to a truncated 26 kD amino-terminal protein and, importantly, a 70 kD carboxy-terminal protein due to alternative translation from a cryptic start site upstream of the deletion. 5
Null mutation of Nbn in the mouse is embryonically lethal 6,7 but mice in vivo and murine cells in vitro can be rescued by ectopic expression of the 70 kD carboxy-terminal nibrin protein. 8,9
Other rarer NBN mutations are also associated with the translation of truncated nibrin proteins. 10
Obviously, these protein fragments retain sufficient functionality to ensure survival.
NBN has been connected to many cellular functions: DNA double strand break repair, cell cycle checkpoint activation, telomere maintenance, meiotic recombination, and immunoglobulin isotope switching.
In all of these roles, nibrin is involved as part of a complex with the ATPase and DNA binding protein RAD50 and the nuclease MRE11 (ref.
Nibrin binds to MRE11 via its carboxy terminal region, and indeed, p70-nibrin also binds MRE11.
It is the same region of nibrin which interacts with ATM to activate the DNA damage response in terms of checkpoint regulation. 11

It is not unreasonable to conclude that survival of NBS homozygotes is attributable to the maintenance of these carboxy-terminal protein-protein interactions whilst their immunodeficiency and malignancy can be ascribed to the lack of protein-protein interactions of the amino terminal region.
3][14][15] Cells expressing only the truncated 26 kD nibrin fragment, containing the FHA and first BRCT domain, are nonviable. 6
edian age at diagnosis of malignancy in NBS is 9.5 years. 4
However, one unique NBS patient, RR, is now 62 years of age and has never developed a malignancy. 16
She is the oldest NBS patient known.
Unlike other NBS patients, this patient has a two base insertion in the vicinity of an exonic splice enhancer in exon 7 of the NBN gene. 17

As a consequence, alternative splicing occurs and an mRNA lacking both exon 6 and exon 7 is produced and translated to a protein of 80 kDa which contains both the carboxy-terminal and the amino-terminal protein interaction domains.
We speculate that this p80-nibrin contributes to RR's milder phenotype and indeed, this protein variant did improve survival of null mutant murine cells in vitro. 17

ince the founder mutation which the majority of NBS patients carry is located in exon 6, directed alternative splicing to remove exons 6 and 7 and generate p80-nibrin could be the basis of an anticancer prophylaxis for NBS patients.
Splicing can be manipulated in cells by introducing antisense oligouncleotides which mask critical sequences. 18,19
1][22] Here we have used antisense oligonucleotides to enforce alternative splicing in NBS cells in vitro and a humanized NBS mouse model in vivo.
Our results demonstrate proof of principle for antisense oligonucleotide directed alternative splicing in NBS.
DNA replication in cell lines expressing p95-nibrin, p80-nibrin, or p70-nibrin Figure 1a shows the exon structure of the NBN gene and the protein and protein fragments derived from it.
In Figure 1b, the three major nibrin proteins are shown in a western blot: p95-nibrin, p80-nibrin, and p70-nibrin.
p95-nibrin is the full-length product of the wild-type gene.
In cells from patients homozygous for the major founder mutation, c.657_661del5, p.K219fsX19, alternative translation leads to a carboxy-terminal product, p70-nibrin. 5
In the patient RR with the homozygous mutation c.742-743insGG, alternative splicing leads to exon skipping and translation of p80-nibrin. 17
This protein lacks sequences from exon 6 and 7 but does carry both amino terminal and carboxy terminal domains, unlike p70-nibrin which lacks the amino terminal BRCT and FHA domains.

Since in addition to DNA repair, nibrin is also involved in DNA replication, 23,24 we examined DNA replication origin firing and elongation rates in cells from NBS patients, including RR, using the DNA fiber assay.
Cells were incubated sequentially in medium

Since the c.657_661del5 founder mutation is located in exon 6, the same alternative splicing observed in cells from patient RR would also effectively remove that mutation, suggesting a potential prophylactic treatment to reduce DNA replication errors and, hopefully, cancer occurrence.
In order to force alternative splicing in NBS patient cells, we searched for exonic splicing enhancers in exons 6 and 7 as targets for oligonucleotide binding.
Using the web-based ESEfinder, 25,26 a cluster of binding sites for splicing factors was found between positions c.636 and c.650 in exon 6 with motif scores between 2.53 and 4.45.
In exon 7, there are Oligonucleotides with the same sequences in sense orientation (SON) were synthesized as controls.
AON were transfected into control and NBS patient cells using a cationic liposome reagent and RNA was isolated over a period of 7 days.

RT-PCR using primers in sequences derived from exons 5 and 10 was used to detect full length and alternatively spliced NBN mRNA: a 579 bp product is derived from the full-length mRNA; the mRNA lacking exons 6 and 7 yields a PCR product of 267 bp.
As shown in Figure 4a, alternative splicing was induced rapidly and efficiently in both control and NBS patient fibroblasts.
The shorter product was sequenced to confirm its origin (Figure 4b).

Already 24 hours after transfection, the fulllength mRNA is fully replaced by the mRNA lacking exons 6 and 7. Four days after transfection full-length mRNA begins to return but even after 7 days a significant amount of alternatively spliced mRNA is still formed.
Transfection of the individual antisense oligonucleotides led to mRNA lacking exon 6 or exon 7, respectively (data not shown).
Since these mRNAs have frameshifts, they are lost during abortive translation due to nonsense-mediated decay.

Examining the NBS patient cells transfected with both antisense oligonucleotides for nibrin protein showed a kinetic compatible with the expression of alternatively spliced mRNA after AON transfection (Figure 4c).
At 24 hours after transfection, a considerable amount of p80-nibrin, the product of the mRNA lacking exons 6 and 7, is present although residual p70-nibrin is still detectable.
Six days later, p80-nibrin is still found although the major NBN product is once again p70-nibrin.
In control cells, p95-nibrin levels were hardly affected and p80-nibrin was not detected (data not shown).
We have previously reported on the considerable stability of p95-nibrin, 27,28 even removing its mRNA for 4 days seems not to significantly alter its abundance.
We examined the kinetics of AON directed exon splicing up to 24 hours in more detail.
As shown in Figure 5, while SON had no effect on nibrin translation, AON again lead to loss of p70-nibrin and production of p80-nibrin.

Using MRE11 as an internal control, we estimated that p80-nibrin production was actually at a maximum 15 hours after AON transfection, while degradation of p70-nibrin lead to p80-nibrin being the major nibrin protein at 24 hours after transfection (Figure 5b).
For experiments in vivo, we exploited the humanized NBS mouse which expresses the major human mutant NBN allele on a null murine background. 9

For transfer, the antisense ESE sequences were synthesized as Vivo-Morpholinos which are specifically designed for in vivo animal studies in which laboratory transfection reagents are inappropriate. 29
Vivo-Morpholinos were first Vivo-Morpholinos were injected into the tail vein of eight mice daily for 4 days before analysis of NBN transcripts by RT-PCR.

As shown in Figure 7a for one treated mouse and one control mouse injected in parallel with an identical volume of sodium chloride solution, the RT-PCR product from the alternatively spliced mRNA was readily detected in several organs.
The semiquantitative analysis for all eight mice shown in Figure 7b indicates the efficiency of directed exon skipping in the organs analyzed.
In the kidney, the alternatively spliced mRNA lacking exons 6 and 7 is practically the only mRNA detected.
Targeting is also very efficient in muscle and liver.
The alternatively spliced mRNA is also formed in the hematological tissues relevant for NBS.
In contrast, targeting efficiency in the brain and gonads was extremely low.
Even though the patient RR had a milder clinical course, at the cellular level there were few differences in DNA repair assays to cells from patients with common c.657_661del5 mutation. 17
owever, as we have recently reported, base mutations occurring during replication probably play a larger role in tumorigenesis in NBS than exogenous DNA damage. 30
Indeed, it is becoming clear that a large proportion of cancer risk in general can be attributed to replication errors rather than environmental challenges. 31
A role for nibrin in DNA replication and the resolution of replication intermediates has been clearly demonstrated earlier. 23,24
Thus DNA replication seemed to be a more pertinent end point to examine in cells expressing p80-nibrin.

In NBS cells expressing the major founder mutation, elongation rates were lower than in control cells, presumably due to replication fork stalling when replication intermediates are inefficiently resolved.
The replication problem at activated forks is reported to result in the firing of further dormant origins [32][33][34] and this is exactly what we observe in these cells.
Cells from patient RR which express p80-nibrin had DNA replication characteristics indistinguishable from control cells.
This possibly reflects the fact that p80-nibrin, unlike p70-nibrin, contains the amino-terminal domains which have been shown to interact with transcription factor E2F at DNA replication origins. 13
However, our attempts to demonstrate a direct interaction between p80nibrin and E2F were unsuccessful, probably due to the extremely low expression level of p80-nibrin (Figure 1b).
Treatment of lymphoma in NBS is particularly challenging since the DNA damage response is impaired in patient cells leading to extreme sensitivity to standard therapeutic measures. 4,35
Thus any treatment which reduces the likelihood of developing a tumor in the first place would be particularly beneficial.
Restoration of wild type NBN by gene therapy would be one approach fraught, however, with the problems of vector delivery and regulated gene expression encountered in other diseases.
Alternatively, oligonucleotide based therapeutics are possibly more amenable.
Among these, antisense oligonucleotides are probably most advanced.

1][22] The strategy employed for muscular dystrophy was forced alternative splicing of a mutated mRNA so that rather than a truncated dystrophin, a molecule with an internal deletion but intact amino and carboxy termini is translated.
Since these domains interact, respectively, with the cytoskeleton and the plasma membrane, the functional superiority of the molecule generated is understandable.

Interestingly, the starting point for the development of this strategy was the original observation that in individual patients with severe truncating dystrophin mutations, low level alternative splicing leads to the production of some functional dystrophin. 38
he data presented in this report on NBS are comparable to the situation in Duchenne muscular dystrophy described above.
A single, malignancy free NBS patient with an alternatively spliced mRNA produces a nibrin protein with an internal deletion but intact amino and carboxy termini.
We show here that this protein corrects the aberrant DNA replication characteristics of NBS cells.
Using antisense oligonucleotides to mask exonic splice enhancers we can direct alternative splicing in cells in vitro and a murine NBS model in vivo.
The extent of alternative splicing varied in various organs, basically as previously observed for directed splicing in the β-globin gene by others. 29
The level of p80-nibrin expression is low even in lymphoblastoid cells from the patient RR, suggesting that the low levels seen in the treated mice might have a significant effect.

Further experiments must follow this proof of principle study, which examine p80-nibrin protein expression in humanized mice after AON treatment, correction of the cellular phenotype in terms of DNA replication rates and, particularly, tumor incidence.
One possible advantage in comparison to the situation in Duchenne muscular dystrophy is the fact that it is not terminally differentiated cells that are the therapy target.
Furthermore, rather than correction of a severe disease symptom such as ambulation, the aim here would be purely prophylactic.
A somewhat comparable situation is given by the recently published use of antisense oligonucleotides to successfully reduce factor XI and thus prevent venous thrombosis. 39
Cell culture and oligonucleotide transfection.

The immortalized human NBS cell lines GM7166VA7 homozygous for NBN c.657_661del5, RR homozygous for NBN c.742-743insGG and a control cell line, LN9SV, transformed with simian virus 40 (SV40) were cultured in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium (Life Technologies, Carlsbad, CA) supplemented with 5% glucose and 10% fetal calf serum strictly in the absence of antibiotics.
Cell culture conditions were 37 °C and 5% CO 2 .
Spontaneous transformed murine fibroblasts were grown from ear explants of the humanized Nbn -/-NBN del5 mouse 9 under the conditions described above.

Synthetic antisense oligonucleotides (Biomers, Ulm, Germany) were applied to exponentially growing cells at 33 nmol/l in the presence of 1.7 µg/ml Lipofectamine 2000 (Life Technologies, Darmstadt, Germany) according to the manufacturer's instructions.

Antisense oligonucleotide sequences were 5′-CUUUCCUGCCGUCCUGACAGAUCAA-3′ complementary to positions c.629-c.653 in exon 6 and 5′-ACAGUCAGGAAUUAAGGUC UGUGAG-3′ complementary to positions c.831-c.855 in exon 7.
As controls, oligonucleotides representing the target sequences were used: 5′-UUGAUCUGUCAGGACGGCAGGAAAG-3′ (exon 6) and 5′-CUCA CAGACCUUAAUUCCUGACUGU-3′ (exon 7).

div.head: Vivo-Morpholino treatment of humanized mice in vivo.

p.s: Vivo-Morpholinos were synthesized by Gene Tools (Philomath, OR) using the same sequences used for the antisense oligonucleotides.
Vivo-Morpholinos have an octa-guanidine dendrimer for penetration of the cell membrane and are stabilized by morpholine rings and phosphoramidate bonds. 29
Humanized NBS Mice, Nbn -/-NBN del5 , were injected in the lateral tail vein daily for 4 days.
The first injection of vivo-morpholinos was at 12 µg/g body weight, the following three injections were at 6 µg/g body weight.
Control mice with identical genotypes were injected with 0.9% sodium chloride.
Mice were killed 24 hours after final injection and organs removed for analysis.
Animal studies were approved by the Landesamt für Gesundheit und Soziales, Berlin (G0438/09).
Immunoprecipitates were washed four times with lysis buffer and proteins were eluted from the beads by boiling for 5 minutes.
Lysates and immunoprecipitates were electrophoresed using the NuPage system (Life Technologies) in 4-12% Bis-Tris polyacrylamide gradient gels.
Following electrophoresis, proteins were transferred to Invitrolon PVDF membranes (Life Technologies).
Membranes were blocked for at least 1 hour in 10% nonfat milk in Tris-buffered saline, pH 7.6, with 0.1% Tween-20 (TBS-T).
Incubation with primary and secondary antibodies was performed in 5% nonfat milk in TBS-T.
All washing steps were carried out using TBS-T.
Immunoblots were probed with monoclonal antibody directed against full-length nibrin (Novus Biologicals) or monoclonal antibody directed against amino acids 182-582 of MRE11 (Novus Biologicals).
Primary antibodies were detected with horseradish peroxidase-conjugated goat anti-rabbit IgG or goat anti-mouse IgG (BD Pharmingen, San Diego, CA).
Chemiluminescence was developed using Western Lightning (PerkinElmer Life Sciences, Boston, MA).
DNA fiber assay.
Fibroblasts were labeled with 25 μmol/l CldU (Sigma-Aldrich, St. Louis, MO) followed by 250 μmol/l IdU (Sigma-Aldrich) each for 45 minutes.
Labeled cells were harvested and DNA fiber spreads prepared on microscope glass slides as described. 40
Fibers were first acid treated and then were stained with monoclonal rat anti-BrdU (AbD Serotec, Oxford, UK) followed by monoclonal mouse anti-BrdU (Becton Dickinson, Franklin, NJ).
As previously described, 41 fibers were visualized with fluorescent secondary antibodies: goat anti-rat Alexa Fluor 555 and goat anti-mouse Alexa Fluor 488 (Molecular Probes, Eugene, OR).
Fibers were examined with the Axioplan 2 (Zeiss, Jena, Germany) fluorescence microscope.
Different types of tracks were classified: ongoing replication, stalled forks, terminated forks, first pulse origins, second pulse origins.
Lengths of CldU and IdU tracks were measured using ImageJ software on images captured with the Axioplan 2 microscope including a standard 20 µm scale bar.
Micrometer lengths were converted into kilobases and replication rates derived from the length of the labeling period.
Figure 1 The NBN gene and nibrin variants.
(a) The exon structure of the gene is shown with the site of the major mutation in Nijmegen breakage syndrome patients.

The full-length nibrin protein, with an apparent molecular weight of 95 kDa and the two protein fragments of 26 and 70 kDa arising from the c.657_661del5 (p.K219fsX19) mutation, and the 80 kDa protein found in patient RR with the mutation c.742_743insGG leading to excision of exons 6 and 7 from the NBN mRNA are shown.
The locations of serine residues targeted by the ATM kinase and acetylated lysine residues are indicated as are the relative locations of the FHA, BRCT, Mre11-binding and ATM-interaction domains.

(b) The blot shows the immunoprecipitation of p95-nibrin, p80-nibrin and p70-nibrin from the indicated SV40 immortalized cells: LN9SV (NBN +/+ ; 2 × 10 6 cells); RR (homozygous for NBN c.742-743insGG; 1 × 10 7 cells); GM7166VA7 (homozygous for NBN c.657_661del5; 5 × 10 6 cells).
Immunoprecipitation with a polyclonal antibody directed to amino acids 395-742 of nibrin; western blot with a monoclonal antibody directed against full-length nibrin.
Due to extreme expression differences short and long exposures of the filter are shown.

CldU or IdU to allow detection of (i) replication forks originating during labeling (either during the first CldU or the second IdU pulse), (ii) forks already fired before labeling, (iii) forks terminating during labeling, or (iv) forks stalled during labeling.
The relative amounts of these different replication figures give insight into the replicative status of the examined cells.

As shown in Figure2a, 17.4% of replication figures in control cells were first pulse origins, while in cells homozygous for c.657_661del5 and expressing p70-nibrin, first pulse origins made up 46.4% of replication figures.

Cells heterozygous for c.657_661del5 and, importantly, cells from patient RR, with the homozygous mutation c.742-743insGG and expressing p80-nibrin, have proportions of first pulse origins comparable to the control cells.
In agreement, as shown in Figure2b, replication rates are significantly lower in cells expressing p70-nibrin than in control cells or cells expressing p80-nibrin (P < 2e−06, Mann-Whitney test).
Figure 2 DNA replication characteristics in Nijmegen breakage syndrome cells with c.657_661del5 or c.742_743insGG NBN mutations.
(a) Control fibroblasts, fibroblasts homozygous or heterozygous for NBN c.657_661del5 and fibroblasts from patient RR homozygous for NBN c.742_743insGG were examined with the DNA fiber assay.
The graph shows the proportion of first pulse origins in the unchallenged fibroblast cultures.
The data are the average and SE for at least 150 replication forks from each of three samples.
(b) The distribution of replication fork rates is shown for the cells examined in Figure 2a.
The data are the average and standard deviation for at least 100 replication forks from each of three samples.
Figure 3 Exonic splice enhancers in NBN.
The sequences of NBN exon 6 and exon 7 are shown together with the positions of sequences to which the splicing factors SRp40, SF2/ASF, and SC35 potentially bind.
The NBN sequences identified as likely exonic splice enhancers are indicated.
Figure 5 Kinetics of directed alternative mRNA splicing.

(a) The immunoblot shows the immunprecipitation of p70-nibrin and p80-nibrin isolated at the given times from Nijmegen breakage syndrome patient cells transfected with sense orientation or antisense oligonucleotides.
IP and WB as described for Figure 4c.
(b) The graphic shows the relative amounts of p70-nibrin and p80-nibrin normalized to the amount of MRE11 as an internal control.
The data are the average and standard deviation of three independent experiments.
Figure 7 Directed alternative mRNA splicing in vivo.

(a) The gel shows the RT-PCR products using primers to detect full-length mRNA and mRNA lacking exons 6 and 7. Top: mRNA isolated from a humanized Nijmegen breakage syndrome mouse injected over 4 days with V-MO.
Bottom: mRNA from a control mouse injected with NaCl.
(b) Organs from 8 V-MO treated humanized mice were assessed for alternative splicing by RT-PCR as in Figure 7a and densitometry of gel photos.
The data give the average and standard deviation for the relative amount of alternatively spliced NBN mRNA in the organs of the eight mice.

figure.head: RT-PCR to detect alternative mRNA splicing

p.s: . RNA was extracted from cells or tissues according to standard procedures (Trizol) and treated with DNaseI to remove contaminating genomic DNA.
For the first-strand cDNA synthesis, 2 µg RNA of each sample, MMLV reverse transcriptase and random hexamer primers were used.

The subsequent RT-PCR reaction used 2 µl of the cDNA product and specific NBN primers: Exon 5.F Exon 10.R producing a 579 bp product from full length nibrin mRNA and a product of 267 bp from mRNA lacking exons 6 and 7 due to alternative splicing.
PCR products were examined on agarose gels.
Gels were scanned for measurement of band intensity and semiquantitative determination of transcript amounts.
NaCl, 5 mmol/l EDTA, and 0.3% Triton X-100 containing a protease inhibitor mixture (Roche Applied Science, Penzberg, Germany).

Lysates were immunoprecipitated with polyclonal antibody directed to amino acids 395-742 of nibrin (Novus Biologicals, Littleton, CO) or polyclonal antibody directed to full-length MRE11 (Novus Biologicals) and Dynabeads Protein G (Life Technologies) for 3 hours.

row.cell: Immunoprecipitation and western blot. Immunoprecipitates were
prepared by lysing transfected cells in 50 mmol/l Tris-HCl pH 7.5,
